required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Optimizing Retention, Duration and Discontinuation Strategies for Opioid Use Disorder Pharmacotherapy (RDD)
clinical_study.official_title: Optimizing Retention, Duration and Discontinuation Strategies for Opioid Use Disorder Pharmacotherapy (RDD)

brief_summary.textblock: This is a two phase study investigating combinations of pharmacological and behavioral interventions to optimize the treatment of Opioid Use Disorder (OUD). The retention phase will assess strategies for improving retention on Buprenorphine (BUP) and Extended-Release Injection Naltrexone (XR-NTX). The discontinuation phase will assess which approaches are most likely to lead to long-term success (absence of relapse), and what characteristics of participants distinguish those who can safely discontinue Medications for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) from those who remain at risk of relapse and should not discontinue.

detailed_description.textblock:
The main objectives of this study are:
1. To test, among patients seeking treatment for OUD, strategies to improve retention in treatment on MOUD.
2. To test, among patients who have achieved stable remission on MOUD and want to discontinue MOUD, strategies to improve outcomes.
3. To develop predictive models of successful discontinuation of MOUD among patients who discontinue medication, based on patient characteristics, including duration of MOUD prior to discontinuation.
The study will have a multicenter, randomized, non-blinded design.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Retention Phase: 3x2 for BUP; 1x2 for XR-NTX; Discontinuation Phase: 2x2 for SL-BUP; 1x2 for XR-BUP; 1x2 for XR-NTX

primary_outcome.measure: Retention phase (R): Continuous retention in treatment at 26 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Binary (yes/no). Continuously enrolled in maintenance treatment on one or more of the evidence-based MOUD modalities (e.g., SL-BUP, XR-BUP, XR-NTX, or methadone maintenance with no more than a 28-day gap in MOUD over the 26-week period.

primary_outcome.measure: Discontinuation phase (D): Completed Discontinuation without Relapse
primary_outcome.description: Binary (yes/no). Discontinuing medication during the study-defined taper period and no relapse to opioid use, either during the taper or during the 24 weeks after MOUD is discontinued.

secondary_outcome.description: Continuous abstinence from opioids in weeks 23-26, measured by TLFB
Continuous abstinence from opioids in weeks 47-50, measured by TLFB
Continuous abstinence from opioids in weeks 71-74, measured by TLFB
Weekly abstinence, measured by TLFB
Craving, measured by the Opioid Craving Scale

Stable abstinence as defined in the study; all criteria must be met (past ≥12 weeks of consecutive abstinence from opioids (other than buprenorphine), methamphetamine, and cocaine, no non-prescribed benzodiazepine use, and no current (≥12 weeks) alcohol use disorder (any severity); measured by Timeline Followback, and DSM-5 checklist for current alcohol use disorder)

Stable abstinence as defined in the study; all criteria must be met (past ≥12 weeks of consecutive abstinence from opioids (other than buprenorphine), methamphetamine, and cocaine, no non-prescribed benzodiazepine use, and no current (≥12 weeks) alcohol use disorder (any severity); measured by Timeline Followback, and DSM-5 checklist for current alcohol use disorder)

Stable abstinence as defined in the study; all criteria must be met (past ≥12 weeks of consecutive abstinence from opioids (other than buprenorphine), methamphetamine, and cocaine, no non-prescribed benzodiazepine use, and no current (≥12 weeks) alcohol use disorder (any severity); measured by Timeline Followback, and DSM-5 checklist for current alcohol use disorder)

secondary_outcome.measure: RS9: Retention in MOUD at week 50
secondary_outcome.description: Point prevalence of retention in MOUD treatment at 50 weeks after date of randomization, measured by TLFB

secondary_outcome.measure: RS10: Retention in MOUD at week 74
secondary_outcome.description: Point prevalence of retention in MOUD treatment at 74 weeks after date of randomization, measured by TLFB
A gap of 28 or more days in MOUD; time to event to have started at the beginning of the 28 day gap, measured by TLFB
Depression, measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) 9 item
Anxiety, measured by the measured by Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) Preference (PROPr)
Stress, measured by the Perceived Stress Scale
Pain, measured by Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) Preference (PROPr)
Recovery capital, measured by the Brief Assessment of Recovery Capital (BARC) 10 item scale

secondary_outcome.measure: RS17: Negative consequences of opioid use
secondary_outcome.description: Negative consequences of opioid use, measured by the Short Inventory of Problems-Revised
Sexual risk, measured by two questions regarding sexual behavior

Treatment effectiveness, measured by the Treatment Effectiveness Assessment (TEA, Ling et. al, 2012); a brief instrument to assess patient progress in treatment and recovery along 4 domains (substance use, health, lifestyle and community)
Rate of incarcerations, collected on the Non-Medical and Other Services form
Rate of homelessness, collected on the Study Demographics form
Discontinued medication during the study-defined taper period and relapse to opioid use, either during the taper or during the 24 weeks after MOUD is discontinued.

secondary_outcome.measure: DS2: Did not Complete Discontinuation with no Relapse
secondary_outcome.description: Medication continued or restarted after discontinuation during the study-defined taper period and no relapse to opioid use, either during the taper or during the 24 weeks after MOUD is discontinued.

secondary_outcome.measure: DS3: Did not Complete Discontinuation with Relapse
secondary_outcome.description: Medication continued or restarted after discontinuation during the study-defined taper period and relapse to opioid use, either during the taper or during the 24 weeks after MOUD is discontinued.
Relapse (time to event) defined as self-reported opioid use on >4 days in any consecutive 28-day period, or 2 or more consecutive opioid-positive drug tests or any self-reported injection drug use

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Withdrawal symptoms, measured by Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Craving, measured by the Opioid Craving Scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Depression, measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ) 9 item

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Anxiety, measured by the measured by Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) Preference (PROPr)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Stress, measured by the Perceived Stress Scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Pain, measured by the measured by Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) Preference (PROPr)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Recovery capital, measured by the Brief Assessment of Recovery Capital (BARC) 10 item scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Recovery capital, measured by the Recovery Capital Scale; six additional questions more specific to participants with OUD

secondary_outcome.measure: DS13: Negative consequences of opioid use
secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Negative consequences of opioid use, measured by the Short Inventory of Problems-Revised

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Sexual risk, measured by two questions regarding sexual behavior

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Incarcerations, collected on the Non-Medical and Other Services form

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of taper and week 24 follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Homelessness, collected on the Study Demographics form

arm_group.description: Standard dose sublingual buprenorphine-naloxone (SL-BUP) 16mg/day target plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
High dose sublingual buprenorphine-naloxone (SL-BUP) 32mg/day target plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
Extended-release injection buprenorphine (XR-BUP) plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
Extended-release injection naltrexone (XR-NTX) plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.

Standard dose sublingual buprenorphine-naloxone (SL-BUP) 16mg/day target plus MMR, consisting of Medical Management and usual counseling, plus reSET-O, a technology-based behavioral component, to support retention and abstinence.

High dose sublingual buprenorphine-naloxone (SL-BUP) 32mg/day target plus MMR, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling, plus reSET-O, a technology-based behavioral component, to support retention and abstinence.

Extended-release injection buprenorphine (XR-BUP) plus MMR, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling, plus reSET-O, a technology-based behavioral component, to support retention and abstinence.

Extended-release injection naltrexone (XR-NTX) plus MMR, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling, plus reSET-O, a technology-based behavioral component, to support retention and abstinence.
Start on SL-BUP, taper with SL-BUP, plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
Start on SL-BUP, taper with XR-BUP, plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
Start on XR-BUP, taper with XR-BUP, plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.
Start on XR-NTX, taper with XR-NTX, plus MM, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling at the treatment program.

Start on SL-BUP, taper with SL-BUP, plus MMD, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling plus Connections, an app-based behavioral component to support discontinuation and recovery.

Start on SL-BUP, taper with XR-BUP, plus MMD, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling plus Connections, an app-based behavioral component to support discontinuation and recovery.

Start on XR-BUP, taper with XR-BUP, plus MMD, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling plus Connections, an app-based behavioral component to support discontinuation and recovery.

Start on XR-NTX, taper with XR-NTX, plus MMD, consisting of standard Medical Management and usual counseling plus Connections, an app-based behavioral component to support discontinuation and recovery.

intervention.description: Monthly dosing of extended-release injection buprenorphine
Monthly dosing of extended-release injection naltrexone
MM consists of standard Medical Management and the usual counseling at the treatment program.
MMR consists of Medical Management and usual counseling, plus reSET-O, a technology-based behavioral component, to support retention and abstinence.
MMD consists of Medical Management and usual counseling plus Connections, an app-based behavioral component to support discontinuation and recovery.

overall_official.affiliation: New York State Psychiatric Institute/Columbia University Irving Medical Center

patient_data.ipd_description: This study will comply with the NIH Data Sharing Policy and Implementation Guidance (https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/data_sharing/data_sharing_guidance.htm) and (for HEAL-funded studies) the HEAL Public Access and Data Sharing Policy (https://www.nih.gov/research-training/medical-research-initiatives/heal-initiative/research/heal-public-access-data-sharing-policy). Primary data for this study will be available to the public in the NIDA data repository. For more details on data sharing please visit https://datashare.nida.nih.gov/. The primary outcome(s) publication will be included along with study underlying primary data in the data share repository, and it will also be deposited in PubMed Central http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/ per NIH Policy (http://publicaccess.nih.gov/).
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Beginning 9 months and ending 36 months following article publication or as required by a condition of awards and agreements supporting the research.
